#Text=How to Get Rid of Mice Naturally
#Text=Having mice in your home is both a nuisance and a health hazard .
#Text=They can cause property damage , create a mess , and produce unpleasant smells .
#Text=In addition , repelling and removing rodents from your home can be a hassle if you do n't know what you are doing .
#Text=It can also be dangerous if you use toxic chemicals and poisons .
#Text=It 's a good thing , then , that there are some simple ways to effectively get mice out of your home without the use of toxic chemicals and poisons .
#Text=Method 1 Discouraging Mice Naturally
#Text=Keep your home clean .
#Text=Many times mice are drawn into homes on the search for food .
#Text=If there is nothing to eat , mice will be less likely to stay .
#Text=Keep all food stored properly in airtight containers or in places that are safe from mouse attack . [ 1 ]
#Text=Apply peppermint oil .
#Text=Peppermint oil is a natural deterrent .
#Text=The smell is simply too intense for rodents and they will not try to go near it .
#Text=It also helps to mask the scent of any tasty morsels that have been missed when cleaning .
#Text=It also gives the house a lovely smell , and is not toxic , unlike many synthetic chemical treatments .
#Text=You can get peppermint oil in most health food stores and even some major grocery stores . [ 2 ]
#Text=Place a drop or two on a cotton ball .
#Text=Place a cotton ball under or near your garbage can to deter mice from getting into it .
#Text=Place the cotton balls in areas where mice are likely to enter your house , by doorways , or heat vents , etc .
#Text=Peppermint oil cotton balls need to be replaced after 5 - 7 days , depending upon the quantity of oil you put on it .
#Text=Try growing peppermint plants near the entryways .
#Text=You can use the mint in cooking , as well as it serving a deterrent purpose .
#Text=Use dried snake feces .
#Text=Visit a local reptile center , zoo , or pet store and ask for some dried snake poo .
#Text=You can also sometimes find someone who owns a pet snake .
#Text=Place near entrances and in places where mice seem to go .
#Text=This will keep mice away . [ 3 ]
#Text=Be sure to keep the feces out of the reach of children and pets .
#Text=Zap mice with ultrasonic sounds .
#Text=There are electronic units sold that emit an ultrasonic beeping sound that rodents hate .
#Text=They should be available at your local home improvement store or online .
#Text=These work only on a single line of sight , so you need to know the exact path the mice are taking .
#Text=The units may only work for a short time because mice can become used to them . [ 4 ]
#Text=Use a commercial , organic deterrent .
#Text=Many companies that specialize in organic garden and home products make mice repellents that are better for the environment than traditional poisons .
#Text=Many of these products use natural ingredients , such as peppermint , that are known to be disagreeable to mice .
#Text=They will not kill mice but they should keep them out of areas where the product is applied .
#Text=These products should be available at your local gardening or home improvement center .
#Text=If you want a specific product , try doing a online search to see where it is available locally .
#Text=Get a cat .
#Text=A house cat can take care of the problem .
#Text=Cats that spend time outdoors are more likely to hunt to find their own food and may track down that mouse .
#Text=Just be aware , not all cats have enough energy , interest or training to hunt mice .
#Text=Kittens typically have to be taught by the mother to easily become a mouser .
#Text=Well-food indoor kitties might just see the mouse as a toy , and grow quickly bored of it after scaring it half witless .
#Text=Shelters and adoption agencies often do not know if a cat is a good mouse hunter , and generally do not test for this .
#Text=Sometimes this information is available , but usually not .
#Text=While many mousers are great pets as well , not all are .
#Text=" Barn cats " may not be socialized well with humans , although used to hunting mice for food .
#Text=Even if you do not have a cat , you can use used kitty litter to deter mice .
#Text=Place tubs of used kitty litter around entrances of the house .
#Text=The mice will sniff the smell of cat urine and clear off in a jiffy .
#Text=If you have a large infestation , a cat may not be enough to totally get rid of it .
#Text=However , once you eliminate the infestation , a cat will probably prevent reinfestation . [ 5 ]
#Text=Put your trash cans far from your home .
#Text=Mice smell garbage and get attracted to your house .
#Text=If you keep the cans away from the house , they are less likely to take up residence in your home .
#Text=Promote the nesting of birds of prey in your yard .
#Text=Build a shelter box in your garden to attract some onto your property .
#Text=This may take some time , but it 's worth the effort if you can attract a wild mouse eater to your yard . [ 6 ]
#Text=Make sure the shelter box has no nails or safety hazards .
#Text=A barn owl is the best .
#Text=A family of barn owls can eat many mice in a night !
#Text=However , you might attract other types of owls or birds of prey with your nesting box .
